Content: Schafer: Oh, Brad is out. Okay.
Hello everybody.
Hi. It's good to see you.
Hello. Thank you for coming.
So, uh, it's Monday, and Friday was terrible.
Uh, all of you were here.
I want to just think everyone for, uh, showing so much class
going through that difficult day.
You guys all, um, uh, held together nicely.
It was a rough day on everybody and, um, I think you showed a lot of compassion
for the people who are leaving and also understanding for those of us who had to make that decision,
and it really helped us get through it.
And we will--we are getting through it, and it's, um...
Now we have a bunch of games we gotta make and stuff to do.
Um, we are still helping the people who need letters of reference,
letters of recommendation, stuff like that.
Help--doing what we can to get them set up with new engagements.
Um, but other than that, we here are still working on these games.
Did you want to talk about the layoffs?
-Is that part of the documentary?
Talk about the layoffs. I'm gonna have a drink.
Can I drink on camera?
If the kids are watchin' this, kids, don't drink.
A week ago, we had a project canceled, an unannounced project from a publisher
that really liked the game.
We had just done our vertical slice and then gave us great feedback on it
and they said it was great and they really liked it.
And then the next call was they're canceling it for higher-up reasons.
Well, that was a big project that was funding a lot of people.
And--and then another one of our publishers from another project is having financial problems
and can't pay us.
Bailey: You know, it's public news now that Majesco is, um...
Pardon me.
Not timed there.
Majesco has made a public statement that
their, you know, continued ability to perform as--as a going concern is at stake and, of course,
we did Costume Quest 2 with them and the payments were not complete for that.
So we're actually-- we're owed money by Majesco that we're not getting paid.
And then, of course Costume Quest 2, um, because of that statement, you can infer
that it's not being marketed properly and it's not being distributed to its fullest extent
that you would expect from a publisher, because there-- you know, the means and the people there to do that
just don't exist anymore.
Um, so it's kind of a perfect storm.
It was a bad week to put it mildly.
So, glad that week's over.
If that publisher hadn't canceled it, you know, things would have been--
were looking really good for the studio.
Um, I think things are still looking really good for the studio,
but only because we took quick action.
Schafer: So we had to let go of 12 people.
Some of them, uh, had been here for a short period of time and some of them had been here for a long period of time,
over ten years.
So that was really hard.
Stoddard: What do you want to know, how I feel about them and-- Off camera: Yeah, yeah, how was it? I mean you--
Stoddard: It was horrible. -Yeah.
It was really horrible. Um...
I mean, I understand why it happened, but, like, we--the audio team was super tight, uh,
and now there's two of us instead of four.
Um, it was a heavy hit.
The day of the layoffs were just brutal.
Kipnis: Uh, well, I will say that the layoffs-- I wasn't actually at the office when it happened, so...
And, um, at first, like, I--I got-- I got text messages about it
and it was, uh...
it was really tough to--to hear about it, um, and it--it was tough to, like, not be here to say goodbye
to some of those people that I've worked with for years and years
and, like, you know, I'm gonna miss a lot.
I don't know what else to say.
Crook: And you always feel a little bit guilty when you're still here, you know, and other people aren't,
um, and it hurts morale quite a bit, um, but...
but I know that it--I know that it was not taken lightly.
Hansen: It was the hardest day of my life.
I never thought we would be in that situation, but project cancelations happen and, you know,
sometimes you can absorb it and sometimes you can't.
So Tim and I almost avoided each other just 'cause we knew that we had to meet and talk about that.
And I didn't want to, and he didn't want to either.
There was no, like, oh, yeah, it's so easy, it's person X, Y, and Z.
It's like every single one of those people are-- they're huge contributors to all these games we've made.
They're the people we hang out with after work and so-- And, you know, and it's tough for Double Fine in general,
because historically, I mean, we even said this in the media in the past,
we don't do layoffs and that sort of thing.
It was--it was a tough decision for sure.
Russell: A lot of us just stayed afterwards in the room, after we were told, and just talked about
the history of the company, and just, we were like, we couldn't believe this happened to us,
but you know, in the game industry and in any entertainment industry,
it's--it's the norm.
We're the exception, so in that respect I-- I--I feel lucky,
and we'll survive, a little bit smaller, a little leaner, but we'll make it.
[Music] Schafer: So basically we are powering forward on our, um,
uh, remaining titles that we're working on.
Those are the stories I really wanted to make the documentary about
but we could never do that, like, those publisher games,
to see, like, what it's like, all those meetings where they're saying,
"This game is so great, we can't wait to see it." And then the meeting where they actually said it's canceled,
we have to cancel it, but I hope you still make it 'cause I really want to play it.
That was an actual quote from the guy, he was like, "If you make it
I really want to play it." It's like, "Oh, thanks, that makes up
for me laying off 12 people.
That--I totally feel good now that you want to play this game
that you just killed." But, um, since I'm mostly fueled by angriness and bitterness,
then I'm stronger than ever right now.
You know, whatever works.
[Music] [Chatter]
Schafer: Oh god, is that thing still here? Mitchell: It's way funnier now.
Muir: It was just sad. Mitchell: Yeah.
Muir: It wasn't bad. Mitchell: No.
Schafer: That one that you found under the sink?
Muir: It's really good. It's like, uh...
Mitchell: It's gooey, though.
Muir: Chipotle.
Schafer: Is everyone here?
[Murmuring] Hello, everybody! Hello.
And thank you for coming back to work here again for another year.
It's awesome to see you all here.
Welcome back.
Nice to see you all.
Rice: Yeah, man.
Schafer: 2015. Wait a second.
Does that mean we didn't finish in December?
Rice: Yeah.
Comin' on three years.
Schafer: Three--no kidding? It's like Rip Van Winkle.
All I remember is the Kickstarter, and then I woke up and it's three years later.
Crook: And we all have big, long--and we all have big, long beards.
Schafer: Yeah, we're just here with beards.
Ray, where did all that money go, what?
I guess we should ship this game.
But the game was awesome.
Um, but, um, but we-- I think I'm trying to this week still keep play testing,
especially the problem areas in the game where people get hung up the most
and catch any remaining dialogue.
There's probably some object interactions or examine lines that are still missing that I would love to catch.
Please keep talking and don't be freaked out that we're not answering you, 'cause we'd just like
to hear what you're thinking.
Miller: All right.
I'm already baffled.
Vella: Is this one?
Miller: This must be incredibly fun to watch.
Schafer: We're not even here.
Miller: What's that? You're not paying attention?
Schafer: Yeah, I'm doing my taxes over here.
Miller: I think I'll switch to Shay 'cause I can't figure this out.
Schafer: I mean, it's--it--that-- the first puzzle, it's, like, one of the first puzzles that Vella has,
and you have to do something and get this visual feedback, and you have to mess with it a lot and get some more feedback
to kind of figure out the patterns.
Um, and then it's just a problem of, like, have we kind of inceptioned? Is that a verb?
Put the idea in the player's head of what they want to do enough.
'Cause sometimes you just mess with the game and you just kind of bang on it
and you--woo, you solved it, you don't really know how you solved it.
And that to me is almost a worst-case scenario.
That's almost worse than getting stuck forever, you know?
Like, getting-- 'cause being stuck forever, if you finally solve it you feel great.
But if you solve it in accident, you're like, I don't know what just happened, you move on
and you kind of get this kind of bored feeling.
And it's really easy to just accidently put this one line in
that makes everybody just know what to do immediately.
So it's--it's like a lot of-- 'cause time--time is short and we don't have much-- we don't have much time left,
and to solve these problems, to make sure that everyone gets through the game,
it's really tempting to just kind of, like, short circuit all the puzzles and make sure
that everybody can get through them.
But you have to kind of take a lot of time to actually really look, um, carefully at, like,
each mental leap the player is making.
[Off camera] If people were saying the first one was too easy and you're taking out a lot of the hints,
I mean, are you afraid you went too far in the other direction?
-It seems like there's a lot-- Schafer: Well, I'm hoping-- I'm hoping we went way too far.
Rice: But yeah, like Tim said, in general I think we're gonna keep play testing
in hopes that anything that we find that is a problem
down the road could be changed.
Crook: Are we gonna have-- with--with Ben leaving, are we having any other-- another GP coming on
or are we gonna be able to just absorb?
Peck: Um, well, it's my second to last day here at Double Fine.
And, uh, just trying to, like, put a bow on as many things as I could before leaving.
The place I'm going to is quite a bit-- it's like a larger company so...
I'm--yeah, I'm gonna miss the...
like, the small little scenes at the lunch table or, like, company meetings and stuff like that
where, like, it's okay to make a dick joke or, like, it's okay to...
to just kind of be yourself a bit.
Um...
I'm hoping I can kind of take a little bit of that for-- like, with me wherever I go, you know?
I feel bad I'm not gonna be there for, like, when the shit inevitably hits the fan, you know,
and the game needs to be finaled.
Kipnis: That jerk.
No, I mean, it sucks.
It sucks. I mean, Ben--Ben contributed a lot to the--to the game and, you know, we're--
we're having to kind of figure out some stuff in the code that he wrote when he could have been here to help us out.
I mean, it sucks, but, um, we'll just have to finish without him, you know?
Crook: I mean, I will say, you know, we've had to transition because, um, Lee left the project
and, um, that was-- that was scary, um, because he--he seemed to know
what was going on with everything.
And so I think Anna's had to take on a lot of some of the responsibilities that Lee had, um,
as far as puzzle chains and--and how those are all put together
and--and the logic.
Um, so I'm sure that's been stressful for her.
[Offscreen] Do you regret not getting to see Broken Age through to the end?
Petty: Yeah, you know, I'm trying to think.
I think this is the only time I haven't stayed on a project
all the way through.
It was a lot of those, um, small decisions right at the end of the project
that have a big impact on the game 'cause all the content's there
and it's all connected.
And sometimes just pushing and pulling a few things
can--it, um, can really help the game, and it's nice to be part of that.
But, uh, I don't think I'll be part of that for Act 2 anyways, but--
I think I'm--I'm excited for Act 2 to come out, because I think Act 1 had a lot of great things about it
but it was incomplete, and, you know, you can sort of see the whole arc or play the whole game,
might get a better sense of whether that was successful or not.
But hopefully I've helped set that up, um, to be a--to be a great experience.
Schafer: But we don't need anybody.
Broken Age team.
We don't-- we don't need nobody.
We'll finish it ourselves.
So where are we supposed to be right now, Alpha on the finale?
Rice: Yeah. You wanna look at the...
Schafer: When is beta on B2 and G2? Is that there?
Rice: Yeah, so we'll show you the timeline as it is right now.
Um, but Matt and Vic and I, and Malena are gonna meet this afternoon now, uh,
and want to get a lot more clarity into just closing out the project,
but also, like, these beta sprints and--and things like that as well.
Hansen: Right now there's a tendency for people to gravitate towards whatever is the, you know,
maybe the most interesting work, and that's not-- might not be the most, uh, highest priority work.
We just need to do some load balancing and some estimates as far as, like, how long is it gonna take
to get this shit done, 'cause people-- if people don't tell us that,
we might be fucked already and we don't even know it.
Rice: Um, but, yes, Ray, you're correct.
The, um, the right reaction to this is, it's a lot to do in two-- in two months and change.
Crook: Yeah. Rice: So, um, I think that's why we wanted to make sure that these dates
get in front of everybody's eyes and that people are looking at it differently.
Hansen: Is it reasonable? I mean, or are you-- or you're like, I don't know, man,
'cause your gut checks are usually pretty good.
Crook: Wow.
Yeah, but I think it's-- I think it'd be all right.
Do you think the GPs are gonna be--I mean, 'cause there was a time where
there were gonna be four of them.
Now there's two of them.
Rice: We're getting all the box stuff ready to go and actually manufacturing in, like, February, um,
to where discs would be pressed in mid-March.
Kipnis: Yeah, and the game--does the game run on the PS4?
Franzke: Nope. Kipnis: Yeah.
And--and I think it's really important to have a, "Okay, Tim, this is it, like, you can't..."
Hansen: Yeah. Kipnis: Like, absolute content complete from, like, Tim content complete maybe.
Hansen: Last call for alcohol.
Kipnis: Yeah, last call.
Let's just call it that, last call.
It's really hard to, as a creator, to turn yourself off.
What I want to do is be able to account for that and I want Tim to be able to do that.
I want him to be able to, like, "Oh, God, this is it, that's right,
I can't add anymore after this." And I want him to be able to, like, have that time
and account for it in our--in our milestone, like, timeline and stuff.
Because I want him to be, like, happy with what we come up with.
Because we know his creative process, it's important for us to schedule it appropriately.
Rice: Yeah, um... Kipnis: Yeah, I didn't realize, like, how soon the beta was.
Jesus Christ. Rice: Yeah, and I don't know, Matt, like, right now every-- there's a lot of hands on Grim,
but, like, obviously that's just a near-term problem that's being solved soon.
But after that, um, yeah, I don't know what kind of, uh, strings
we can pull with people on other teams, um, as needed.
Hansen: They can't. I mean, we have milestones. We won't get paid.
If we don't get paid then the studio shuts down.
Rice: That's what I thought.
So I was just making sure that that was the case.
Hansen: I'm just gonna be totally blunt with you guys, but you can't touch (redacted).
Kipnis: Yeah. Hansen: I'm sorry.
Franzke: Yeah.
All right. Rice: Cool.
Franzke: Let's make this happen, huh?
Rice: Yeah. All right.
Like, you guys are the right people to ask about this.
Like what--what does gut say about the timeline?
It's basically two months till pencils down.
Inversin: I'm not totally scared just yet, but I might be terrified.
We'll see.
[Offscreen] Did you get to learn anything from Lydia when she was still here?
Panya: No.
She had a lot of the Act 1 shader stuff, so, like, her signature's over everything
so I can pick up where she left off in that sense.
Uh, but she's not here for me to kind of ask questions.
Scheduling with effects is always kind of scary, 'cause there's always this, you know,
four-week window at the end for polish, and, of course everybody wants to polish at the end,
even design wants to polish, and that trickles down.
Animations get tweaked at the end, and then visual effects and sound effects
are the last two guys to kind of get, uh, to touch it.
So as long as everyone knows that the sound effects and the visual effects guys are last and they give some buffer,
then we shouldn't be too, uh, too screwed.
Stoddard: I want to make sure German gets hit because we have to re-volume graph
and re-special effects process all of the German recording for Act 1 and Act 2, and that's a tall order.
Rice: Yeah, and it's getting delivered beginning of February, right, and then don't we--is the plan to have outsourcer on it
that should take, like, three weeks?
Stoddard: We--yeah. Hansen: We have Ashley coming in.
Stoddard: Yeah. Hansen: And she'll be, uh, helping...
-...specifically for this work. Rice: Yeah.
Schafer: I would like to ask you to join me in welcoming Ashley Coull to Double Fine.
There she is over there.
Ashley.
Coull: You know, a contract. It's a short amount of time and, you know, there-- there's no--there's no guarantee,
and it was a staggering amount of work as well, but, uh, the opportunity to be here
and be a part of this community, uh, Camden even pulled me out-- pulled me out of work one day,
and I think he got about halfway through the sentence of, "Hey, so there's this contract thing," and I was like, "Yes."
And he was like, "I--uh, yeah," and I was like, "Yeah." Um, and that's kind of how--how
the balls got--got rolling, I guess.
Schafer: Because we have German VO in the game, which is awesome, and it sounds crazy. I started playing it.
I mean, I don't mean crazy, I mean in a language that is not my own.
-German Vella: Hallo? Schafer: There we go.
[Coughing] That's a German cough, obviously.
[Disproving sigh] [Laughter]
I really like the German version. I'm gonna play through the whole thing in German.
Stoddard: Yeah, that was-- that was a-- the was a big, big thing,
so she's just-- she's kicking ass, Paul is kicking ass.
He really is stepping up.
I mean, it's like kind of both their moments to step up.
O'Rourke: I mean, it's always enjoyable. Tim's writing is hilarious most of the time
and it's really good to just-- like, usually when I'm editing--
I don't want to talk bad about, like, sports games or anything,
but if I had to edit, like, Madden dialogue all day,
probably kill myself.
But going through Tim's stuff is actually pretty enjoyable.
Um, I gave him a huge cut scene the other day.
Dude, here's a big moment, go do it,
come back when it's done.
And he came back and it was damn near perfect.
Like he nailed it, so I'm like, okay, I'm not worried anymore.
The layoffs were not good, um...
It's definitely-- This--this company is under stress.
Everybody is being super pro and they're making good product, but, like, it's-- it's heavy duty right now.
And I'm just really happy to see this team kind of gel, uh, you know, in the trenches and really get it.
Me?
(speaking in German) [Offscreen] What was that? Franzke: I--what?
[Laughter] Coull: Uh, I said I'm editing all the German lines.
Franzke: Can I read-- can I read this?
[Laughter] Franzke: Oh.
Rice: We've gone through this now with all the leads, yeah,
but, um, yeah, now we wanted to present it it to you.
The next week is-- Schafer: Last set call.
Rice: Huh? Schafer: Tim last call...
Rice: Yeah, we'll get to that.
So like, tomorrow the hope is during stand-ups to, like, relay this whole thing to the entire team,
not just the leads.
And I feel like we gotta kinda give, like,
a bit of a sense of urgency and just, like, that kind of thing.
But I feel like it's also trying to put people's fears to rest, which would--I think one of the big ones is that,
like, we're gonna continue to iterate on the game...
-...and things like that. Schafer: So terrify them with the deadlines and put all their fears to rest.
Rice: And then hopefully, uh, just pep rally, pump people up?
Schafer: If we use the words "dig deep" at any point, I'm just-- Hansen: Will you say it? Schafer: No.
Rice: No. Schafer: There's always a point where someone talks about digging deep,
and I just-- I don't want to say that.
So we all gotta dig deep, you guys.
Hansen: All right. Rice: Yeah, I pro-- I think I might put the dates
on the whiteboard again, too, just so everyone can look at them all the time.
Schafer: If they view that, they'll film it.
Rice: Yeah, red, white, and blue.
Romero: That's encouraging.
Broken Age, fuck yeah.
Schafer: Does that help?
Romero: Tim last call. Is that a milestone?
Rice: Fuck yes. Romero: Okay.
We submit to ratings boards on the fourth?
Rice: Yeah, I think it's that-- Kipnis: When do we know what line...?
Crook: Tim said he would try to call him. When he said you're hitting the line, it's okay.
Maybe I just gotta try to find one that...
Rice: Ready? So we've been meeting production team with the leads
to come up with closing plan stuff.
So next Friday we have our next Sony milestone, which Oliver is working on.
I think the big thing is PlayStation 4 running.
Schafer: Is there anything on there new or shocking to anyone?
Crook: It's all shocking, but nothing's new.
There's nothing new.
Schafer: There is a lot of stuff to do in a short amount of time,
but there's no big unknowns to me, at least, on it.
There's no design yet to do, dialogue yet to write, and big ques--
things that could explode into-- I mean, like, it seems like it's a known amount of work now
that can't expand, and, um, and it's clear that it can't slip
because you can see the commitments that are on it.
As far as I'm concerned, like, everything is just no-- everything just has to be pushed through the machinery,
and that's the easy part, except for it's hard.
No, we're--we're the dream team, all here together.
For some reason, to me it's always relaxing when it's finite even if it is tight
because you know when it's gonna be over.
These next three weeks are really where the game goes from being good to great mostly.
So, um, it's gonna be exciting and, uh, if we have to order food,
we'll order food.
Crook: Food.
Boston Market?
Schafer: No. Crook: Promise Boston Market, I'll-- Schafer: Wait, you want Boston-- Crook: I'll work late if you--
No, I'm just kidding. Kipnis: Wow.
Crook: Just kidding.
Schafer: If you've gotta lure a man away from his family, make it Boston Market.
Crook: Yeah.
Schafer: It's like there's love in that meal.
Kipnis: That's--that's what Caroline did for us during Psychonauts.
Remember that? Rice: Boston Market?
Kipnis: Boston Market, like, every night.
Crook: Yep. Kipnis: And, uh, and I gained-- I gained, like, 15 pounds during during crunch.
Schafer: That's to keep you in your seat.
[Music] Schafer: Uh, on "Reds," we did a whole play-through of the team
of the finale of the game to figure out how to push that towards, um, completion.
We are also starting on the PS4 version.
Hansen: So we have a milestone on the 23rd, and that's to have it, like,
"playable," um, on that platform, so-- But it looks like that's come along really well,
so good job, Oliver.
Schafer: Look at it playing on the PS4.
[Offscreen] How's the port process been going in general?
Franzke: It's good. We essentially added PlayStation 4 and PlayStation Vita
to a list of platforms, but kept the ship date the same,
um, so that makes things a bit more interesting.
I love working on consoles, but it's a very different kind of challenge, like,
for example, the Vita is very memory constrained, um, so that, you know,
it's--it's a very tight memory budget for--for the game, and if you're just leaking some memory somewhere,
like, you're gonna have a bad time later on, so there are, like, a lot of really interesting things
you need to take into consideration.
Or can you compress the data in some way and stuff like that.
And I think the end-- the end will be tough, for sure, shipping.
Like, so, for--for consoles, um, what you have to do in order to release games
is you have to go to something that's called certifications.
The next milestone is on the 20th, which is-- like, it's very ominously called, like, beta
which is supposed to be TRC complete, uh, essentially for Sony
so there's a lot of stuff that needs to happen before that.
Those are all the requirements you need for shipping a game on a--on a Sony platform.
Schafer: I'm sure we're TRC complete.
Franzke: Oh, yeah, no problem.
Um, so they will essentially, like, run a game and make sure that every one of those requirements is met.
[Offscreen] How does stuff like Assassin's Creed happen?
Oliver: Uh, I'd rather not comment on that.
It's really sad, because I'm pretty sure all the people who worked on the game, you know,
didn't want to release something that's substandard.
Um, so very often, it's--it's-- actually really sad for the developers,
but there's a lot of, like, pressure from various departments
to make the game happen essentially.
Are you feeling some form of pressure like that now?
Well, I mean, but if you-- if you don't have a publisher who's, like, does what, uh, needs to happen,
but as you can see, everything is so tightly packed, uh, that there's really no time to slip any of those milestones.
Franzke: Yes, please. -Okay.
See, crunch has already started.
Schafer: Yeah, we're getting near the end where some nights people are working late
and we're ordering food, and, um...
and hopefully that won't be too long till it's over.
And people who are staying late now, it's 'cause they want to make sure the game is really good.
[Music] I know the biggest hurdle is just the amount
of work there is to do.
Uh, we have to do a whole bunch of cut scenes.
Still have to go in.
Crook: Camden there was the issue with, uh, Bob Chothra coming out of the mountain
that we were gonna-- did you talk to Tim about that and Peter?
I don't know about-- I'm in that scene still.
We're making some changes, so I just-- Stoddard: Okay.
Schafer: Just saying that gave Ray a headache.
Offscreen: How is the ending cut scene coming along, since that was sort of, uh-- that had to be--
the music had to be done, so that was kind of locked.
Schafer: Yeah, yeah, 'cause we kind of locked it, but I feel good about the pacing of that, just based on the music.
Um, and it was so big we had to split it between two animators, Miyuki and Chris Lam.
So Miyuki was doing the first half and Chris was doing the second half.
And then we're gonna stitch it back together.
Oh, I like that. That's a good idea.
Crook: Yeah, that was really good.
That's cute.
Richardson: Like, uh, so many characters, and...
and it's kind of a big thing, right?
It's ending, end of the game, so that's kind of exciting, but still goin' like,
"Ooh, that's a lot of things to do." Crook: Maybe not the happy eyes? Lam: No.
Schafer: Yeah, like, the delirious eyes, like yay, he's more like...
Hm.
"You run, I got this." Crook: All right. Schafer: "Save yourself."
Thumb's up.
Crook: Yeah, he got that on film. We might need to...
Schafer: This ping pong ball, his face.
Lam: The parts that I have to do that are kind of those, you know, resolution moments,
they're gonna be a little challenging but-- to get the expressions on the characters right
so that you know that they're thinking, they're not just staring into dead space and stuff like that.
Crook: Think you got enough info there?
Okay. Lam: Yes.
Crook: The plan is to just take it to that, um, shippable stage.
And then, uh, that will allow all the effects and the sound to get put in, um, 'cause all the timing will be locked down.
So the--the plan is that they'll go back to it, uh, to do some polish, um,
after we get all the content in.
Schafer: Is this a good time to look at it?
